metadata.title: Surface Treatment on Recycled Coarse Aggregates with Nanomaterials

sections.text: Author keywords: Recycling; Nanotechnology; Concrete aggregates; Interfaces.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Presently, excessive discharge of construction and demolition (C&D) wastes has become a worldwide problem. According to the 2nd International Conference on Waste Engineering and Management (Li 2013) held in Shanghai, 2010, the annual discharge of C&Dwastes around the world will exceed 10 billion tons. In the United Kingdom, approximately 110 million tons of C&D wastes are generated yearly, accounting for more than 60% of the country’s total waste (Paine and Dhir 2010). In Hong Kong, it has been estimated that the annual generation of C&D wastes could be as much as 14 million tons (Rao et al. 2007). According to incomplete statistics, in China, waste concrete account for at least 50% of all the C&D waste (Quan 2009). Waste concrete collected from the C&D wastes can be crushed and sieved to produce recycled aggregate (RA). RA can be further consumed by using it to replace part or all of the natural aggregate (NA) in concrete mixtures, to then produce recycled aggregate concrete (RAC). RAC not only provides a method of disposing of C&D wastes but also helps reduce the consumption of NA.
A number of studies have been completed regarding the properties of RAC, which have been found to be commonly inferior to natural aggregate concrete (NAC) not only in mechanical properties
(Corinaldesi 2010; Gómez-Soberón 2002; Poon and Chan 2007; Topcu and Şengel 2004) but also in durability properties (BuyleBodin and Hadjieva-Zaharieva 2002; Günçan 1995; Henry et al. 2011; Olorunsogo and Padayachee 2002; Rahal 2007; Zhu et al. 2013).
To enhance the properties of RAC, researchers have developed diverse modifying treatments using different materials. Currently, nanotechnology attracts considerable interest in the construction industry because of the potential uses of particles on the nanometer scale in concrete mixtures. Modification effects of nanosilica (nSi) particles, on the properties of NAC have been well studied (Ji 2005; Sobolev and Gutiérrez 2005) and the corresponding mechanism has been revealed. Generally, nanosilica particles work at two levels in cement-based materials, i.e., the filling effects attributable to the smaller size of nanoparticles (Qing et al. 2007) and the accelerating effects because of the pozzolanic activity or perhaps the surface activity of nanosilica (Björnström et al. 2004; Lin et al. 2008; Sakulich and Li 2011; Senff et al. 2009). Some researchers also proved that nano-CaCO3 (nCa) particles, also called nanolimestone particles, can enhance properties of cement-based materials as well. The nanolimestone powder can function as a fine-grade filler in cement-based materials, providing additional surfaces for the nucleation and growth of hydration products, according to Bentz (2006). Bonavetti et al. (2001) pointed out that the ground limestone could be slightly reactive with the portland cement, mainly forming a monocarboaluminate phase. Bentz et al. (2012) also verified that the particle sizes of the limestone powders are a key variable factor influencing their performance as accelerators of reaction and setting of cement-based materials.
Although the modification effects and the corresponding modification mechanism of nanomaterials like nSi and nCa particles on the NAC properties have been explored in detailed experiments, the application of nanomaterials on the RAC mixture has seldom been considered. RA is a three-phase material containing not only the old virgin aggregate and the adhering cement mortar but also the old interface transition zones (ITZs) between each material. After RA was introduced into RAC, at least two types of ITZs were produced, i.e., the old ITZs between the old aggregate and the adhering old mortar; and the new ITZs between the old and new mortars, as shown in Fig. 1. ITZs are commonly the weak points in

3Associate Professor, Institute of Building Materials, College of Civil Engineering and Architecture, Zhejiang Univ., Hangzhou 310058, Zhejiang, People’s Republic of China. E-mail: taomeng@zju.edu.cn
4Emeritus Professor, Center for Advanced Cement-Based Materials, Dept. of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Northwestern Univ., Evanston, IL 60208. E-mail: s-shah@northwestern.edu
Note. This manuscript was submitted on October 22, 2014; approved on April 29, 2015; published online on July 2, 2015. Discussion period open until December 2, 2015; separate discussions must be submitted for individual papers. This paper is part of the Journal of Materials in Civil Engineering, © ASCE, ISSN 0899-1561/04015094(11)/$25.00.

cement-based materials (Ollivier et al. 1995; Prokopski and Halbiniak 2000). Old mortar adhering to the old virgin aggregate in RA is also generally porous and weak, which may lead to further weakness in RAC (Etxeberria et al. 2006). Therefore, whether nanomaterials like nanosilica and nano-CaCO3 can work in all the potential weak points in RAC (i.e., the old ITZs, the new ITZs, and the old adhering mortar) and how they can modify RAC’s properties on the macroscale, needs further exploration. Moreover, to date, nanomaterials are only applied in functional concretes or in high-performance concrete, primarily because of the high cost (Sari et al. 1999; Senff et al. 2009). Therefore, if nanomaterials intend to be widely applied in RAC modifications, their dosage has to be controlled to ensure the economic efficiency of the target RAC projects.
This paper aims to provide an effective and economical modification technique for RAC by applying surface treatment on RA with the use of nanomaterials. Two strengthening slurries with the incorporation of different nanomaterials were prepared and used to treat the surface of RA. The nanoindentation technique was applied to evaluate the mechanical properties of different types of ITZs and mortars in RAC quantitatively on the microscale. The physical properties of RAwere tested before and after the surface treatment; the macroproperties of the corresponding concrete, using the treated or untreated RA, were also tested and compared. This research assessed the feasibility of using nanomaterials in RAC modifications and revealed the mechanism of the modification effects of the nanoslurries used on RAC’s properties. Based on the results of this research, the cost of the surface treatments on RA with nanomaterials can be controlled.

sections.heading: Coarse Aggregate
sections.text:
The NA used in this study was crushed limestone with the size ranging from 5 to 25 mm. untreated RA was purchased from a manufacturer in Shanghai, China. The RA’s original size ranged from 5 to 35 mm. To fine-tune the RA to be within the same size range as the NA, the RAwas crushed by a jaw crusher (maximum sieve opening of 100 mm) and then sieved by a screen. The untreated NA and RA were labeled as N0 and R0, respectively. The gradation information of N0 and R0 is shown in Fig. 2, in which, for R0 samples, aggregate particles of larger size (more than 16 mm) accounted for a greater proportion compared with the N0
samples, which indicated that the average size of the untreated R0 were bigger than that of the N0. Still the difference in size gradation was acceptable, therefore, the influence of grain size distribution of coarse aggregates on macroproperties of concrete might be ignored.

sections.heading: Strengthening Slurries
sections.text:
In this study, two types of slurries containing different nanomaterials were prepared. The first slurry mainly contained nSi and nCa, which can be labeled as the nSi + nCa slurry. Considering the high price of nanomaterials, the other slurry, which can be labeled as the Cement + nSi slurry, reduced the dosage of nano-SiO2 but added more cement as a substitute. The proportions of the components contained in the two types of nanoslurries are provided in Table 1.
Surface treatment of RAwas achieved by soaking the aggregates in the corresponding nanoslurries. First, the two types of strengthening slurries with good dispersion were prepared by mixing the corresponding strengthening materials with water for 120 s. Afterwards, the untreated RA was added into the corresponding slurry and soaked for 45 min. The RA was then removed from the bath, and a screen was used to remove the redundant nanoslurry adhering to the RA. The final step of the process was to dry the RA at a temperature of 20 2°C and a relative humidity of 64 5% for at least 3 days.
The RA samples treated by the nSi + nCa slurry and the Cement + nSi slurry were labeled as R1 and R2, respectively. Therefore, four coarse aggregate groups were prepared to include the

The untreated and treated RA samples, shown in Fig. 3, were R0, R1, and R2, from left to right. Fig. 3 demonstrates that, after surface treatment, a coating formed on the surfaces of R1 and R2, primarily attributable to the precipitation of the particles contained in the two nanoslurries.

sections.heading: Mixture Proportions
sections.text:
By using the four groups of coarse aggregate (N0, R0, R1, and R2), a total of four groups of concrete mixtures were produced, labeled as NAC0, RAC0, RAC1, and RAC2, respectively. The target compressive strength of the four concrete groups was 30 MPa.
Mixture proportions of the four concrete groups are illustrated in Table 2.
A series of 100- and 150-mm cubes were prepared for each group of concrete. After casting, all specimens were moist cured in a curing chamber at a temperature of 20°C and a relative humidity of more than 95%.

sections.heading: Microproperties
sections.text:
To determine the mechanical properties of the four concrete groups on a microscale, a Hysitron 950 Triboindenter, fitted with a Berkovitch tip (tip radius of 0.6 μm and angle of 142.3°), was used to administer nanoindentation tests on different phases of the RAC at the ages of 3 and 28 days. At the ages of 3 and 28 days, small concrete slices with dimensions of 10 × 10 × 5 mm were cut from the 100-mm concrete cubes, to prepare the nanoindentation
samples. Considering the significant influence of samples’ surface roughness on the reliability of nanoindentation tests (Miller et al. 2008), it was necessary to carefully grind and polish these concrete slices before indentation to obtain adequately even and smooth testing surfaces. In this study, the procedure for sample processing mainly referred to the technique designed by Li et al. (2012).
The high-resolution probe microscopy installed in the Triboindenter allowed observation and in situ image capturing, thereby one was able to precisely locate the desired indent areas before indentation. In this study, nanoindentation was conducted on or around all the potential weak points in RAC, i.e., the old ITZs, the new ITZs, and the old mortars, to reveal the modification effects of the two nanoslurries on different weak points, separately. The indent areas across old ITZs in the three RAC groups and the conventional ITZs in the control concrete, NAC0, were 100 × 100 μm squares. A denser zone was found between the old and new cement mortar, as shown in Fig. 4; therefore, the indent areas across the new ITZs were enlarged to 150 × 100 μm to ensure that the new ITZs were completely covered. The denser zone probably formed before concrete casting, on the surface of old cement mortar adhering to RA, by the carbonation of the unhydrated CaðOHÞ2 in the old cement mortar when RAwas directly exposed to the atmosphere (Li et al. 2012). For both old and new ITZs at each of the testing ages, four indent areas were tested. For nanoindentation on old mortars, five indent areas with the dimension of 30 × 30 μm were selected for each group of RACs, labeled as OM-1 to OM-5 according to their distances away from the old mortars’ surface, as shown in Fig. 5. Taking RAC0 at the age of 28 days, for example, OM-1 was the closest one to the new ITZ whereas OM-5 was the farthest away. Indentation modulus of new mortars were obtained in the same way. Different indent matrices were accordingly designed on indent areas of different dimensions. As demonstrated in Figs. 6(a and b), a 21 × 11 matrix and a 31 × 11 matrix were designed for the 100 × 100 μm and 150 × 100 μm indent areas, respectively. A 4 × 4 matrix was applied for the 30 × 30 μm areas on the old mortar and the new mortar in RAC, as shown in Fig. 6(c).
In this study, an identical single-cycle loading path was applied on all the indent areas. In each cycle, the indenter first came into contact with the sample surface gradually, with the load increasing at a constant rate of 120 μN to the maximum value of 1,200 μN. Afterwards, the peak load was kept for 2 s, then the indenter lifted gradually, until the indenter finally left the sample surface and the load declined to zero.
Fig. 3. RA before and after surface treatment using different nanoslurries

E ¼ ð1 − v2Þ × 1 Er − ð1 − v 2 i Þ Ei −1 ð1Þ
In this study, the indenter’s elastic modulus, Ei, is 1,140 GPa and its Poisson’s ratio, vi, is 0.07. The Poisson’s ratio of the tested samples, v, is suggested as 0.2 (Li 2008) for RAC, which is the same with that for NAC. The reduced elastic modulus, Er, is obtained from nanoindentation tests.

sections.heading: Coarse Aggregate Properties
sections.text: The properties of coarse aggregate, i.e., the apparent density, crushing value, and water absorption (by weight), of the four groups of coarse aggregates were tested according to GB/T 14685-2011 (Standards Press of China). Crushing value is a parameter used to reflect the strength of aggregates, which is defined as the ratio of the crushed aggregate particles to the original aggregate by mass. The larger crushing value, the poorer resistance of the tested aggregates to compressive loads.

sections.heading: Workability of Fresh Concrete
sections.text: The slump of fresh concrete was tested according to GB/T 50080- 2002 (China Architecture & Building Press 2002b).

sections.heading: Compressive Strength of Hardened Concrete
sections.text:
At an age of 28 days, three 100-mm concrete cubes were crushed to test the compressive strength, based on GB/T 50081-2002 (China Architecture & Building Press 2002a).
Chloride Ion Diffusion Coefficient of Hardened Concrete The rapid chloride migration (RCM) method was used to achieve the Cl− diffusion coefficients of concrete in this study, at an age of 28 days, based on GB/T 50082-2009 (China Architecture & Building Press 2009).The specimens used in RCM tests were cylindrical with diameters of 100 1 mm and heights of 50 2 mm.
The Cl− diffusion coefficient was calculated as follows:
DRCM ¼ 0.0239ð273þ TÞL ðU − 2Þt " Xd − 0.0238 ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ð273þ TÞLXd U − 2 r #
ð2Þ where T = mean value of the initial and final temperature of the anode solution; L = height of the concrete cylinder; U = voltage applied to the system; t = power-on period; and Xd ¼ Cl− diffusion depth, achieved from the chromogenic reaction between Cl− and AgNO3 solution.

sections.heading: Microproperties
sections.text:
By using the contour-color fill function of the OriginPro 9.0 software, the modulus distribution map of each indent area across the ITZs was plotted using different shades to represent the different modulus ranges. Average widths of each type of ITZ, based on the modulus distribution maps of four randomly selected indent areas, were thereby obtained and discussed. The probability distribution of the elastic modulus of the different weak points was compared among the four concrete groups to offer quantitative evidence of the mechanical property changes on the microscale.
Properties of ITZ in NAC0 Fig. 7(a) shows an example of optical positioning of the target indent area across ITZ in NAC0 at an age of 3 days before indentation. Fig. 7(b) shows the modulus distribution within this indent area after data processing with Origin.
In Fig. 7(b), the three different phases, i.e., aggregate, ITZ, and cement mortar, can be easily distinguished from one another by their differences in shading, representing the different modulus ranges. In this way, the boundaries of ITZ contained in this indent area can be determined, as marked in Fig. 7(b). Hence, the width of this ITZ can be determined to be approximately 40–45 μm.
Similarly, the width of other ITZ samples for NAC0 at the ages of 3 and 28 days can be obtained. The average widths of NAC0 ’s

ITZ were discovered to be 40 and 35 μm, at the ages of 3 and 28 days, respectively, indicating that the width of NAC0 ’s ITZ had declined through this period of time. Cement hydration may contribute to such development, as cement hydration can help fill the pores in cement-based materials. NAC0’s ITZ will be compared with old ITZs in the three RAC groups in the next section.

sections.heading: Effects of Surface Treatment on the Properties of Old ITZs in RACs
sections.text:
By using the data processing method previously stated, the average widths of the old ITZs in the three RAC groups at the ages of 3 and 28 days could be achieved, as summarized in Table 3.
According to Table 3, no large differences among the old ITZs could be determined on the basis of width among the three groups of RACs. Meanwhile, the width of the old ITZs contained in all three RAC groups did not develop over time. Such results will be discussed in depth in the following parts of this section.
Once the left and right boundaries of the target ITZ were determined, the elastic modulus data obtained within the boundaries
were collected; statistical analyses were conducted to determine the probability distribution of the modulus within the ITZs. The probability distribution of the modulus within the old ITZs in the three RAC groups at the ages of 3 and 28 days were plotted and compared in Figs. 8(a and b), respectively. The results obtained from NAC0’s ITZ are also shown in Fig. 8 and served as the control.
Fig. 8 demonstrates that from the age of 3 days through the age of 28 days, the elastic modulus of old ITZs in the three groups of RAC experienced little development because the probability distribution curves of the modulus shown in Fig. 8(a) were comparable to those shown in Fig. 8(b) for RAC0, RAC1, and RAC2, respectively. Such results could be explained because cement hydration in these old ITZs was no longer significant because the age of RAwas usually several decades and the contained unhydrated cement particles in the adhering cement mortar and the old ITZs had been almost consumed. By contrast, the micromechanical properties of the NAC0’s ITZs had developed as time passed, as seen in not only the decrease in width (40 μm at the age of 3 days; 35 μm at the age of 28 days) but also the gain of elastic modulus
Fig. 6. Indent areas and corresponding indent matrices on different phases: indent matrix (a) across ITZs in NAC0 and across old ITZs in three groups of RAC; (b) across new ITZs in RAC; (c) on old and new mortar

[see differences between Figs. 8(a and b)]. A large amount of unhydrated cement particles existed in NAC0’s ITZs at its relatively early age; the continuous hydration of these cement particles contributed largely to these ITZs’ development in mechanical properties.
According to both Table 3 and Fig. 8, at both of the two testing ages, the old ITZs of the three groups of RACs were comparable to one another in either width or probability distribution of the elastic modulus. Such results demonstrate that neither of the two nanoslurries used in this study significantly enhanced the mechanical properties of the old ITZs. Through the surface treatment procedure, neither RA1 nor RA2 were soaked in the nanoslurries for long (approximately 45 min). As a result, the nanoparticles and the cement particles were unable to deeply penetrate into the old cement mortar or arrive at the old ITZs inside the RA, so that the old ITZs could not be significantly enhanced.

sections.heading: Effects of Surface Treatment on the Properties of New ITZs in RACs
sections.text:
Similarly, the average widths of the new ITZs contained in the three RAC groups at the ages of 3 and 28 days were achieved, as summarized in Table 4.
According to Table 4, the new ITZs in all three RAC groups had developed from the age of 3 days through the age of 28 days, as the widths of these ITZs declined significantly during this period of time.
To further compare the micromechanical properties of the new ITZs among the three groups of RACs, the probability distribution of the modulus in the new ITZs at the ages of 3 and 28 days was plotted, as shown in Figs. 9(a and b), respectively. The elastic modulus of the new ITZs in all three groups of RACs had experienced significant development. At the age of 3 days, the peaks of the three probability distribution curves, as shown in Fig. 9(a),

fall in the ranges of 5–10 GPa, 10–15 GPa, and 10–15 GPa for the new ITZs in RAC0, RAC1, and RAC2, respectively. At the age of 28 days, as shown in Fig. 9(b), the three peaks shift to the right to the highermodulus ranges (10–15 GPa, 15–20 GPa, and 15–20 GPa, respectively). Similarly, continuous cement hydration in these new ITZs may also be the predominant reason for the property development of new ITZs over time, reflected by both the width decrease and the modulus gain.
According to both Table 4 and Figs. 9(a and b), the properties of the new ITZs in RAC1 and RAC2 were superior to those of the new ITZs in RAC0. Such results are reflected by the smaller width and the higher elastic modulus level of the new ITZs in RAC1 and RAC2 compared with RAC0. Therefore, the two nanoslurries used in this study have beneficial effects on RAC’s new ITZs. Water absorption of RA1 and RA2 were proved to be reduced compared with the untreated RA0, which will be presented in the “Results and Discussion” section. Therefore, in RAC1 and RAC2, the water stored in RA1 and RA2 was reduced and thereby the amount of water penetrating from the old mortar to the surrounding new ITZs was reduced as well. In this way, the water-to-binder ratio in new ITZs was cut down, which may have contributed to the enhancement of the new ITZ. As can be observed in Fig. 3, a thin coating formed around RA1 and RA2 attributable to the precipitation of strengthening particles throughout the 45-min soaking in the nanoslurries. When the surface-treated RA1 and RA2 were cast into concrete specimens, nanomaterials and cement particles contained in the coating may probably dissolve and penetrate back into the new surrounding ITZs, thereby inducing filling effects and accelerating effects. Hydration of cement particles contained in the Cement + nSi slurry could densify the new ITZs as well.
To further verify the enhancing effects of RAC1 and RAC2’s new ITZ, Fig. 10 was plotted to illustrate the elastic modulus within the new ITZs’ boundaries in relation to the distance away from the surface of old mortars, or in other words, from the new ITZs’ boundaries on the old mortar side. Each curve represents the average level of the four randomly selected indent areas. According to Fig. 10, at both the ages of 3 and 28 days, elastic modulus within RAC0’s new ITZ did not illustrate an obvious trend to show whether it increased or decreased away from the old mortar’s surface. By contrast, for new ITZs of RAC1 and RAC2, generally, elastic modulus decreased as the distance away from old mortar’s surface increased, in spite of fluctuations. Such results further verify that the enhancement of new ITZs of RAC1 and RAC2 may be probably induced by the dissolving and penetration of nanomaterials or cement particles in the thin coating around RA1 and RA2, respectively. However because these particles were not able to penetrate deeply into the new ITZs from the surface of the old mortars (i.e., in the new ITZs of RAC1 and RAC2), the modulus far away from the old mortars’ surfaces was no longer significantly enhanced.
Both Figs. 9 and 10 indicate that the enhancing effects of the two nanoslurries on the properties of the new ITZs in the RACs were comparable to one another; the gaps between the RAC1 and RAC2 curves are small. Such results prove that by using the Cement + nSi slurry prepared in this study, even though the content of nanosilica is greatly reduced, the beneficial effects on properties of RACs can be ensured compared with the nSi + nCa slurry. Therefore, the designed Cement + nSi slurry may have better prospects in RAC’s modification, chiefly considering the smaller dosage of expensive nanomaterials used while guaranteeing the enhancing effects on RAC, primarily on the new ITZ properties. Such results are further discussed subsequently by comparing the modification effects of the two nanoslurries on the macroproperties of RAC.

sections.heading: Effects of Surface Treatment on the Properties of Mortars in RACs
sections.text:
Nanoindentation test results obtained on old and new mortars in the three groups of RACs, at an age of 28 days, are shown and compared in Fig. 11. Fig. 11(a) shows that the old mortars of RAC1 and RAC2 seems to be slightly stronger than that of RAC0. Average modulus of the five indent areas, as previously illustrated in Fig. 5, is shown in Fig. 11(b). In RAC1 and RAC2, the average modulus of the OM-1 area, which was closest to the surface of old mortars, was larger than those farther away; although in RAC0 all five indent areas did not demonstrate obvious differences in modulus. Such results indicated, that in RAC1 and RAC2, old mortars were possibly surface strengthened, thereby explaining why the old mortars in RAC1 and RAC2 showed enhanced modulus as indicated by Fig. 11(a). Throughout the RAs’ soaking in nanoslurries, although most strengthening materials precipitated on the RAs’ surface, some strengthening materials, primarily the nanoparticles, may penetrate into the adhering old mortar and strengthen the old mortar. However, nanomaterials or cement particles were unable to penetrate deeply into the old mortar, explaining why enhancement of the old mortar was quite limited.
No obvious differences were observed in the probability distributions of the modulus of new mortars among the three concrete

groups, as shown in Fig. 11(c). Such results indicate that the two nanoslurries used did not enhance the properties of the new mortars in RAC. Even though some nanoparticles or cement particles contained in the coatings around R1 and R2 could possibly penetrate back into new ITZs, nevertheless, as illustrated by Fig. 10, nanomaterials or cement particles had not crossed new ITZs. Therefore, it was reasonable to conclude that new mortars were not enhanced.

sections.heading: Coarse Aggregate Properties
sections.text:
Apparent densities, crushing values, and water absorptions of the four aggregate groups (i.e., the untreated coarse aggregates, N0 and R0; and the surface-treated RAs, R1 and R2) are illustrated in Table 5.
The apparent densities of the three groups of RAs were all smaller than that of N0. The existence of the porous adhering cement mortar to RA decreased the average compactness of RA and, thereby, reduced the density of RA. The untreated and treated RAs demonstrated no obvious differences in apparent density, as shown in Table 5, likely because the materials contained in both types of nanoslurries were relatively light in weight. Thus, the precipitation of the lightweight strengthening particles on the RAs’ surface or the small amount of particles penetrating into the old mortar did not significantly influence the apparent density of RA.
The crushing value and water absorption of N0 were much lower than those of R0, R1, and R2, as shown in Table 5. The more porous, weakly adhering mortar around RAwas also the possible predominant reason for the inferiority of RA to NA, in terms of resistance to crushing and water absorption. After the surface treatment using either of the two designed nanoslurries, the crushing values and water absorption of the RAs were reduced, indicating that the RAs got stronger after the surface treatment with nanomaterials. As previously discussed, the old mortars of R1 and R2 were surface strengthened by the penetration of nanoparticles. Thus, surface strength of R1 and R2 was improved so that the anticrushing capability of the two treated RAs increased. Similarly, because pores around the old mortars’ surface were filled, water absorption of the two groups of surface-treated RAs was thereby controlled.

sections.heading: Workability of Fresh Concrete
sections.text:
Slumps of the four groups of fresh concrete are shown in Fig. 12.
Slump test results of the four groups of fresh concrete were consistent with the water absorption results of the coarse aggregate used, as exhibited in Table 5. Therefore, the differences in water absorption of coarse aggregates directly led to the diversity in workability among the four concrete groups. The beneficial effects of surface treatment, using the two nanoslurries, on the workability of RAC were certified because the slump of RAC1 and RAC2 had been significantly improved compared with that of RAC0. According to Fig. 12, the slump of RAC1 was comparable to that of NAC0, indicating that the inferior workability of RAC will no longer limit

sections.heading: Compressive Strength of Hardened Concrete
sections.text:
The cube compressive strength of the four concrete groups at the age of 28 days is shown in Fig. 13.
According to Fig. 13, by using the surface-treated RA, the compressive strengths of RAC1 and RAC2 were moderately improved. The new ITZs in RAC1 and RAC2 were significantly enhanced. This enhancement on the microscale provides the mechanism of the modification effects of the two nanoslurries on RAC’s mechanical properties on the macroscale.
However, although the compressive strength of RACs was improved by the surface treatment using nanomaterials, it was still inferior to that of NAC. As stated in the “Introduction,” RAC contains more weak points than NAC, i.e., the porous adhering cement mortar, and the more types of ITZs including the old ITZs and the new ITZs. Although the new ITZs were enhanced by the two nanoslurries used, the other two weak points in RAC, i.e., the old ITZs and the old adhering cement mortars, were not strengthened or were merely surface strengthened.
Furthermore, Fig. 13 shows the enhancing effects of the Cement + nSi slurry were better than those of the nSi + nCa slurry, in terms of improving RAC’s compressive strength, which is consistent with the more significant enhancement of the new ITZs with the use of the former slurry, as indicated by Fig. 9.
Chloride Ion Diffusion Coefficient of Hardened Concrete The Cl− diffusion coefficients of the four concrete groups at an age of 28 days, as obtained from RCM tests, are shown in Fig. 14.
Fig. 14 demonstrates that by employing the surface-treated RA, the resistance to Cl− diffusion of RAC1 and RAC2 was significantly improved. Such results were closely related to the enhancement of the new ITZ in RAC, which helped reduce the penetration paths for Cl−. The surface-strengthened old mortar may also contribute to preventing Cl− diffusion. The modification effects of the Cement + nSi slurry on RAC’s resistance to Cl− diffusion were better than those of the nSi + nCa slurry. Such results are consistent with the nanoindentation modulus results obtained from the new ITZs, as indicated by Fig. 9. As illustrated in Fig. 14, the Cl− diffusion coefficient of RAC2 decreased to a level that was comparable to that of NAC0, indicating that the modification effects of the surface treatment using the Cement + nSi slurry were more significant, than those achieved using the nSi + nCa slurry, in terms of improving RAC’s resistance to Cl− diffusion.

sections.heading: Relationship between the Microproperties and Macroproperties
sections.text:
Although the old ITZs in RAC were not enhanced, because the nanomaterials or cement particles contained in the two slurries were unable to penetrate far enough into the old mortar to yield the old ITZs, the properties of the new ITZs in RAC were significantly enhanced. The old mortar, however, was likely surface strengthened. The surface-strengthened old mortar contributed to the enhancement of RA’s resistance to crushing and water absorption. As a result of the decrease in the water absorption of RAs, the workability of the corresponding concrete, RAC1 and RAC2, was improved. The improvement of both new ITZs and old mortar resulted in higher compressive strength and greater resistance to Cl− of RAC1 and RAC2 because the destructive and penetration paths in the two modified RACs were reduced by the nanomaterials.
The enhancing effects of the two nanoslurries on the macroproperties of RAs and RACs were verified to be comparable. In most cases the Cement + nSi slurry, which contained more cement but

These results indicated that the Cement + nSi slurry may be a good alternative, to those strengthening slurries or solutions containing more nanomaterials, in modifying RAC, particularly when considering its advantages in terms of both low cost and the guaranteed modification effects on RAC.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
The conclusions of this study are summarized as follows: • The width and elastic modulus of the old ITZs in RAC did not
develop as time passed, regardless of surface treatment on RA using nanomaterials, mainly because few unhydrated cement particles existed in the old ITZs and nanomaterials were not able to penetrate into the old ITZs. • The new ITZs in RAC containing RAs surface treated by either of the two nanoslurries (i.e., the nSi + nCa slurry or the Cement + nSi slurry) were significantly enhanced. The width of the new ITZs in the modified RACs was reduced, whereas the elastic modulus obtained from nanoindentation tests was proved to be significantly improved compared with the unmodified RAC. • The old mortar adhering to RAwas surface strengthened by the two nanoslurries used, and thereby improved the resistance of RA to crushing and water absorption. • The slump of fresh RACwas improved by using the RA surfacetreated with either of the two nanoslurries used in this study. Surface strengthening of old adhering mortar to RA may be the predominate reason for such results. Compressive strength and resistance to Cl− diffusion of RAC were significantly enhanced by using the surface-treated RAs, which were closely related to the enhancement of new ITZs in the two modified RACs. • The Cement + nSi slurry is a good alternative to those nanoslurries containing more nanomaterials. This alternative not only has lower cost, due to the controlled dosage of nanomaterials, but also provides guaranteed modification effects on both the mechanical properties and durability of RAC.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: Financial support from the National Specialized Research Fund for Doctoral Program (20120101110025) and the New Century Excellent Talents in University (NCET-12-0493) are gratefully acknowledged. The authors also want to express thanks to Dr. Gajendra Shekhawat, at Northwestern University, for his support. Nanoindentation tests in this work used the NIFTI facility (NUANCE Center-Northwestern University).

referenceMentions.context: According to the 2nd International Conference on Waste Engineering and Management (Li 2013) held in Shanghai, 2010, the annual discharge of C&Dwastes around the world will exceed 10 billion tons.
In the United Kingdom, approximately 110 million tons of C&D wastes are generated yearly, accounting for more than 60% of the country’s total waste (Paine and Dhir 2010).
In Hong Kong, it has been estimated that the annual generation of C&D wastes could be as much as 14 million tons (Rao et al. 2007).
According to incomplete statistics, in China, waste concrete account for at least 50% of all the C&D waste (Quan 2009).

A number of studies have been completed regarding the properties of RAC, which have been found to be commonly inferior to natural aggregate concrete (NAC) not only in mechanical properties (Corinaldesi 2010; Gómez-Soberón 2002; Poon and Chan 2007; Topcu and Şengel 2004) but also in durability properties (BuyleBodin and Hadjieva-Zaharieva 2002; Günçan 1995; Henry et al. 2011; Olorunsogo and Padayachee 2002; Rahal 2007; Zhu et al. 2013).
Modification effects of nanosilica (nSi) particles, on the properties of NAC have been well studied (Ji 2005; Sobolev and Gutiérrez 2005) and the corresponding mechanism has been revealed.

Old mortar adhering to the old virgin aggregate in RA is also generally porous and weak, which may lead to further weakness in RAC (Etxeberria et al. 2006).
Moreover, to date, nanomaterials are only applied in functional concretes or in high-performance concrete, primarily because of the high cost (Sari et al. 1999; Senff et al. 2009).

Considering the significant influence of samples’ surface roughness on the reliability of nanoindentation tests (Miller et al. 2008), it was necessary to carefully grind and polish these concrete slices before indentation to obtain adequately even and smooth testing surfaces.

metadata.abstractText: Surface treatment, using two slurries containing nanomaterials, was applied to recycled aggregate (RA). Experimental studies were conducted (1) to compare properties of RA before and after the surface treatment; and (2) to examine the modification effects of the surface treatment with nanomaterials on the microstructure and macroproperties of recycled aggregate concrete (RAC). The nanoindentation technique was used to achieve elastic modulus of different interface transition zones (ITZs) and old and new mortars in RAC. Test results show that both nanoslurries enhanced new ITZs between the old and new cement mortars. Although they did not work on old ITZs between the virgin aggregate and the old cement mortar, old mortars were surface strengthened. It is also proved that properties of both RA and RAC on the macroscale were improved by the surface treatment using nanomaterials. DOI: 10.1061/(ASCE)MT.1943-5533.0001368. © 2015 American Society of Civil Engineers. Author keywords: Recycling; Nanotechnology; Concrete aggregates; Interfaces.
